Home: Benjamin F. Perry, who served as provisional governor of South Carolina in 1865.
Benjamin and his wife Elizaeth Frances McCall had nine children.
The family lived in Greenville, South Carolina, where Benjamin practiced law and owned a newspaper.
South Carolina: South Carolina experienced dramatic political changes from antebellum period through Reconstruction.
Major institutions founded: Erskine College (1850), Furman College (1850), Wofford College (1851), and several women's colleges.
The state seceded from the Union and was readmitted during Reconstruction, adopting new constitutions in 1865 and 1868.
National: Period spans from John Tyler's presidency (1842) through James A. Garfield's presidency (1881).
Major events include Mexican-American War (1846-1848), Compromise of 1850, Civil War (1861-1865), and Reconstruction (1865-1877).
Significant legislation: Wilmot Proviso (1846), Compromise of 1850, 15th Amendment (1870), Compromise of 1877.
International: Mexican-American War (1846-1848) resulted in U.S. territorial expansion.
Period of European colonial expansion and industrial revolution globally.

South Carolina: Benjamin F. Perry declines renomination for legislature.
National: Waddy Thompson, Jr. appointed U.S. Minister to Mexico.

Home: Benjamin and Elizabeth's third child, son Frank, is born.
Perry is out of debt and owns $17,420 worth of property.
Perry purchases 80 acres of agricultural and timberland in Greenville District and 6 months later purchases an adjoining 120 acres.
Perry is invited to give address at Pendleton Agricultural Society's 30th anniversary meeting. John C. Calhoun was in attendance.
South Carolina: John C. Calhoun seeks Democratic nomination for president, but loses to James Polk
Calhoun appointed Secretary of State by President John Tyler
John C. Calhoun elected to U.S. Senate

Home: Perry embarks on his tour to Washington, D.C., New England and Canada. He was distressed over the neglected appearance of southern countryside on his return home.
South Carolina: Work begins on Greenville RR.
Perry is elected by legislature as a member of the Board of Trustees of South Carolina College.
John C. Calhoun encourages adoption of Oregon Treaty
International: Oregon Treaty signed by Secretary of State James Buchanan

Home: Benjamin and Elizabeth's fourth child, daughter Anna, is born.
National: Abraham Lincoln elected to U.S. House of Representatives as Whig candidate from Illinois
California requests entrance to Union as free state

Home: Perry founds The Southern Patriot newspaper with contributions by Vardry McBee and Waddy Thompson, Jr.
South Carolina: John C. Calhoun dies
Erskine College receives its charter, Presbyterian
Furman College receives its charter, Baptist
National: Slave trade abolished in Washington D.C.

Home: Benjamin and Elizabeth's fifth child, son Hext, is born.
South Carolina: Wofford College receives its charter, Methodist

National: Harriet Beecher Stowe publishes Uncle Tom's Cabin

South Carolina: Greenville Female Baptist College opens
Newberry College receives its charter, Lutheran

Home: Benjamin and Elizabeth's eldest daughter, Anna, dies of tuberculosis in January
South Carolina: Columbia Female College opens, Methodist

Home: Benjamin and Elizabeth's son, Frank, dies of tuberculosis in July
South Carolina: Due West Female College opens, Associate Reformed Presbyterian
William Gilmore Simms publishes History of South Carolina
Greenville County established
Greenville occupied by Union forces until May 2nd
President Andrew Johnson appoints Benajamin F. Perry as provisional governor of South Carolina. He serves from June 30 to December 21, 1865.
South Carolina adopts its fifth state constitution abolished slavery and institued popular election of the governor and presidential electors.
Severe drought decimates crops
DeForest describes Greenville as bankrupt
South Carolina adopts its sixth state constitution

Home: Benjamin and Elizabeth's son, Hayne, dies of tuberculosis
